posts.cooked:
Hello I have a question, so I write a topic.

Q1. I have created and used the Shuffleboard Widget in the program. However, when you download the robot program, the widget is disabled like the image below. (Data cannot be adjusted) Shutting down and turning on the Shuffleboard solves the problem, but it’s hard to turn it off and on every time you download it. Is there a solution to this problem? Q2. I want to measure encoder pulses every 20 ms for PID control.This is to make sure that it has reached the target speed. As shown in the image below, the encoder data seems to be shaking a lot. Is it normal? (We use the frc/Encoder library and program it with C++) 1 413×527 17.8 KB

1 413×527 17.8 KB

1 413×527 17.8 KB

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
Posting your code (or a link to your code) would be very helpful.

Re: Shuffleboard, are you looking to control the motor using this slider?  This is typically only enabled when your robot is enabled in Test mode (which enables LiveWindow).

Re: Shuffleboard, are you looking to control the motor using this slider?  This is typically only enabled when your robot is enabled in Test mode (which enables LiveWindow).

Without seeing the code, it’s unclear what you’re plotting.  Is this a velocity measurement read from the Encoder class using GetVelocity()?  Or are you measuring the position in your code and subtracting it?  Both have potential sources of noise.  Where is the encoder hooked up in the mechanism (e.g. how fast is the encoder shaft actually spinning)?

Without seeing the code, it’s unclear what you’re plotting.  Is this a velocity measurement read from the Encoder class using GetVelocity()?  Or are you measuring the position in your code and subtracting it?  Both have potential sources of noise.  Where is the encoder hooked up in the mechanism (e.g. how fast is the encoder shaft actually spinning)?

This widget is created by the program. I attached the code image below. All other widgets, not necessarily the slider that controls the motor, have the same problem. (Disable after downloading the program)

I want to know the encoder pulse counter measured for 20 ms. And we will control the DC motor using PID control using the measured encoder pulse. That’s why I hope there’s no noise in the encoder pulse. (I attach the code image below) (Create a new thread and repeat the encoder measurement program.)

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked: Here ’s some working C++ code that does something very similar.  Some of the arguments you’ve used look suspicious.

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
So you are plotting Δposition, or discrete velocity.  This averages (visually) somewhere around 39 encoder ticks per unit time.  How are you measuring time?  One way is:

It’s likely you can improve things to make the data less jittery, but more detail is needed.  What type of encoder?  How is it connected?  Link to code (or more code)?
